languages.text: "Однажды утром я привел к вратам бастиона сотню детей, что мы пленили во время нашего победоносного марша, и предложил генералу обмен — его жизнь на их жизни. Генерал, чья воля была крепче адамантиума, отказался. Тогда я умертвил детей на глазах защитников бастиона и ушел. На следующий день я явился вновь с очередной сотней, и снова предложил обмен. Генерал вновь отказал, и еще сотня кричащих и рыдающих детей сгинула от моей руки. На третий день, когда я явился к вратам с очередной сотней, избитого и израненного генерала сбросили со стен к моим ногам сами защитники крепости".

"One morning, I walked to the bastion's gates with a hundred children whom we had captured on our triumphant march, and offered the general a trade — his life in exchange for theirs. The general, whose will was stronger than adamantine, refused. I then put the children to death before the defenders' eyes and left. The next day, I came again with another hundred and made my offer once more. Again the general refused, and another hundred screaming, crying children died by my hand. On the third day, when I approached the gates with a hundred more, the general, beaten and wounded, landed at my feet, cast down from the walls by the bastion's defenders."
languages.original_text: "Однажды утром я привел к вратам бастиона сотню детей, что мы пленили во время нашего победоносного марша, и предложил генералу обмен — его жизнь на их жизни. Генерал, чья воля была крепче адамантиума, отказался. Тогда я умертвил детей на глазах защитников бастиона и ушел. На следующий день я явился вновь с очередной сотней, и снова предложил обмен. Генерал вновь отказал, и еще сотня кричащих и рыдающих детей сгинула от моей руки. На третий день, когда я явился к вратам с очередной сотней, избитого и израненного генерала сбросили со стен к моим ногам сами защитники крепости".

traits.locale_text: "One morning, I walked to the bastion's gates with a hundred children whom we had captured on our triumphant march, and offered the general a trade — his life in exchange for theirs. The general, whose will was stronger than adamantine, refused. I then put the children to death before the defenders' eyes and left. The next day, I came again with another hundred and made my offer once more. Again the general refused, and another hundred of screaming, crying children died by my hand. On the third day, when I approached the gates with a hundred more, the general, beaten and wounded, landed at my feet, cast down from the walls by the bastion defenders."

On the third day, when I approached the gates with a hundred more, the general, beaten and wounded, landed at my feet, cast down from the walls by the bastion defenders."

"One morning, I walked to the bastion's gates with a hundred children whom we had captured on our triumphant march, and offered the general a trade — his life in exchange for theirs. The general, whose will was stronger than adamantine, refused. I then put the children to death before the defenders' eyes and left. The next day, I came again with another hundred and made my offer once more. Again the general refused, and another hundred screaming, crying children died by my hand. On the third day, when I approached the gates with a hundred more, the general, beaten and wounded, landed at my feet, cast down from the walls by the bastion's defenders."

languages.text: « Un matin, je me suis présenté devant les portes du bastion avec une centaine d'enfants capturés lors de notre marche triomphante et j'ai proposé un marché au général : sa vie en échange de la leur. Hélas, son opiniâtreté était telle qu'il n'a rien voulu entendre. Alors, j'ai exécuté les enfants sous les yeux des défenseurs et je suis reparti. J'ai remis ça dès le lendemain, le général a refusé à nouveau et une autre centaine d'enfants en pleurs sont morts de ma main. Le surlendemain, quand je suis arrivé à leurs portes avec un troisième groupe d'otages, le corps meurtri du général a atterri à mes pieds, précipité du haut des murs par ses propres hommes. »
languages.original_text: "One morning, I walked to the bastion's gates with a hundred children whom we had captured on our triumphant march, and offered the general a trade — his life in exchange for theirs. The general, whose will was stronger than adamantine, refused. I then put the children to death before the defenders' eyes and left. The next day, I came again with another hundred and made my offer once more. Again the general refused, and another hundred screaming, crying children died by my hand. On the third day, when I approached the gates with a hundred more, the general, beaten and wounded, landed at my feet, cast down from the walls by the bastion's defenders."

traits.locale_text: « Un matin, je me suis présenté devant les portes du bastion avec une centaine d'enfants capturés lors de notre marche triomphante et j'ai proposé un marché au général : sa vie en échange de la leur. Hélas, son opiniâtreté était telle qu'il n'a rien voulu entendre. Alors, j'ai exécuté les enfants sous les yeux des défenseurs et je suis reparti. J'ai remis ça dès le lendemain, le général a refusé à nouveau et une autre centaine d'enfants en pleurs sont morts de ma main. Le surlendemain, quand je suis arrivé à leurs portes avec un troisième groupe d'otages, le corps meurtri du général a atterri à mes pieds, précipité du haut des murs par ses propres hommes. »

languages.text: «Una mañana, me acerqué a las puertas del bastión con un centenar de niños que habíamos capturado en nuestra marcha triunfal, y ofrecimos un intercambio al general: su vida por la de los jóvenes. El general, cuya voluntad era más fuerte que el adamantino, se negó. Entonces ejecuté a los niños bajo la mirada de los defensores y me marché. Al día siguiente, volví a presentarme con otro centenar y repetí mi oferta. El general se negó una vez más, y una vez más cien niños murieron a mis manos, entre gritos y llantos. Al tercer día, cuando me acerqué con cien más, el general, magullado y herido, cayó a mis pies, empujado desde los muros por los defensores del bastión».
languages.original_text: "One morning, I walked to the bastion's gates with a hundred children whom we had captured on our triumphant march, and offered the general a trade — his life in exchange for theirs. The general, whose will was stronger than adamantine, refused. I then put the children to death before the defenders' eyes and left. The next day, I came again with another hundred and made my offer once more. Again the general refused, and another hundred screaming, crying children died by my hand. On the third day, when I approached the gates with a hundred more, the general, beaten and wounded, landed at my feet, cast down from the walls by the bastion's defenders."

traits.locale_text: «Una mañana, me acerqué a las puertas del bastión con un centenar de niños que habíamos capturado en nuestra marcha triunfal, y ofrecimos un intercambio al general: su vida por la de los jóvenes. El general, cuya voluntad era más fuerte que el adamantino, se negó. Entonces ejecuté a los niños bajo la mirada de los defensores y me marché. Al día siguiente, volví a presentarme con otro centenar y repetí mi oferta. El general se negó una vez más, y una vez más cien niños murieron a mis manos, entre gritos y llantos. Al tercer día, cuando me acerqué con cien más, el general, magullado y herido, cayó a mis pies, empujado desde los muros por los defensores del bastión».

languages.text: 「ある朝、私は凱旋行軍で捕らえた100人の子供たちを連れて城門に向かい、将軍に交換条件を申し出た。彼の生命を、この子らと引き換えると。将軍の意志はアダマンチウムよりも堅固であり、それを拒んだ。その後、私は子供たちを守備隊の目の前で殺し、その場を去った。翌日、私はまた別の100人を連れて再び戻り、同じ提案をした。将軍はまたもや拒否し、泣き叫ぶ別の100人の子供たちが私の手によって死んだ。三日目、私がさらに100人を連れて城門に近づくと、将軍は打ちのめされ傷だらけになり、要塞の守備隊によって城壁から投げ落とされ、私の足元へと転がった」
languages.original_text: "One morning, I walked to the bastion's gates with a hundred children whom we had captured on our triumphant march, and offered the general a trade — his life in exchange for theirs. The general, whose will was stronger than adamantine, refused. I then put the children to death before the defenders' eyes and left. The next day, I came again with another hundred and made my offer once more. Again the general refused, and another hundred screaming, crying children died by my hand. On the third day, when I approached the gates with a hundred more, the general, beaten and wounded, landed at my feet, cast down from the walls by the bastion's defenders."

traits.locale_text: 「ある朝、私は凱旋行軍で捕らえた100人の子供たちを連れて城門に向かい、将軍に交換条件を申し出た。彼の生命を、この子らと引き換えると。将軍の意志はアダマンチウムよりも堅固であり、それを拒んだ。その後、私は子供たちを守備隊の目の前で殺し、その場を去った。翌日、私はまた別の100人を連れて再び戻り、同じ提案をした。将軍はまたもや拒否し、泣き叫ぶ別の100人の子供たちが私の手によって死んだ。三日目、私がさらに100人を連れて城門に近づくと、将軍は打ちのめされ傷だらけになり、要塞の守備隊によって城壁から投げ落とされ、私の足元へと転がった」

languages.text: “某天早晨，我带着一百个孩子走到要塞门口，那些孩子是我们在胜利进军期间俘虏的。我向那位将军提出了一笔交易，用他的命来换那些孩子们的命。那位将军的心肠比铁石还要硬，他拒绝了，于是我当着所有守军的面屠光了那些孩子，之后离开了。第二天，我又带着一百个孩子过来，再次提出了同样的交易，但那位将军又拒绝了，于是又有一百个哭喊不止的孩子死在了我手上。到了第三天，当我又带着一百个孩子接近城门的时候，那位将军已经倒在了地上，遍体鳞伤，是被要塞的守军从城墙上扔下来的。”
languages.original_text: "One morning, I walked to the bastion's gates with a hundred children whom we had captured on our triumphant march, and offered the general a trade — his life in exchange for theirs. The general, whose will was stronger than adamantine, refused. I then put the children to death before the defenders' eyes and left. The next day, I came again with another hundred and made my offer once more. Again the general refused, and another hundred screaming, crying children died by my hand. On the third day, when I approached the gates with a hundred more, the general, beaten and wounded, landed at my feet, cast down from the walls by the bastion's defenders."

traits.locale_text: “某天早晨，我带着一百个孩子走到要塞门口，那些孩子是我们在胜利进军期间俘虏的。我向那位将军提出了一笔交易，用他的命来换那些孩子们的命。那位将军的心肠比铁石还要硬，他拒绝了，于是我当着所有守军的面屠光了那些孩子，之后离开了。第二天，我又带着一百个孩子过来，再次提出了同样的交易，但那位将军又拒绝了，于是又有一百个哭喊不止的孩子死在了我手上。到了第三天，当我又带着一百个孩子接近城门的时候，那位将军已经倒在了地上，遍体鳞伤，是被要塞的守军从城墙上扔下来的。”

languages.text: "Eines Morgens ging ich mit hundert Kindern, die wir auf unserem Triumphzug gefangen genommen hatten, zu den Toren der Bastion und machte dem General ein Angebot ... sein Leben im Tausch gegen das ihre. Der General, dessen Wille stärker war als Adamant, lehnte mein Angebot ab. Also tötete ich die Kinder vor den Augen der Verteidiger und ging. Am nächsten Tag kehrte ich mit hundert anderen Kindern zurück und wiederholte mein Angebot. Der General lehnte es erneut ab und so starben wieder hundert kreischende und weinende Kinder durch meine Hand. Als ich mich am dritten Tag mit hundert weiteren Kindern den Toren näherte, landete der General verprügelt und verwundet vor meinen Füßen, nachdem ihn die Verteidiger der Bastion von der Mauer geworfen hatten."
languages.original_text: "One morning, I walked to the bastion's gates with a hundred children whom we had captured on our triumphant march, and offered the general a trade — his life in exchange for theirs. The general, whose will was stronger than adamantine, refused. I then put the children to death before the defenders' eyes and left. The next day, I came again with another hundred and made my offer once more. Again the general refused, and another hundred screaming, crying children died by my hand. On the third day, when I approached the gates with a hundred more, the general, beaten and wounded, landed at my feet, cast down from the walls by the bastion's defenders."

Am nächsten Tag kehrte ich mit hundert anderen Kindern zurück und wiederholte mein Angebot. languages.text: "Zafer dolu ilerleyişimiz sırasında ele geçirdiğimiz yüz çocuğu da yanıma alarak bir sabah hisarın kapılarına yürüdüm ve generale takas teklif ettim: Onun yaşamına karşılık onların yaşamı. İradesi adamantinden daha sert olan general, teklifimi reddetti. Ardından çocukları, savunucuların gözleri önünde katlettim ve oradan ayrıldım. Ertesi gün yüz çocukla daha geri döndüm ve teklifimi yineledim. General tekrar reddetti ve yüz çocuk daha çığlıklar içinde ellerimde can verdi. Üçüncü gün yüz çocukla daha kapılara yaklaştım. Dövülmüş ve yaralanmış hâldeki general, hisarın savunucuları tarafından duvardan aşağı atılarak ayaklarımın dibine düştü."
languages.original_text: "One morning, I walked to the bastion's gates with a hundred children whom we had captured on our triumphant march, and offered the general a trade — his life in exchange for theirs. The general, whose will was stronger than adamantine, refused. I then put the children to death before the defenders' eyes and left. The next day, I came again with another hundred and made my offer once more. Again the general refused, and another hundred screaming, crying children died by my hand. On the third day, when I approached the gates with a hundred more, the general, beaten and wounded, landed at my feet, cast down from the walls by the bastion's defenders."
